it’s honestly kinda hard to say at this point. I’ve used it in projects but honestly I’ve mostly resorted to not using it now unless I run into a serious performance issue, as the browsers automatically handle performance for animations fairly well.

The implementations for browsers have changed a few times on how will-change kicks in. the basic understand I have though is that will-change should generally be set by javascript(or a css class that is added by javascript) before an animation is triggered, to make it more efficient. leaving it always there, is a bad thing performance wise

yup that’s the one i was reading… seems like they both do the same thing (trigger the GPU for rendering) but will change is the preferred newer school method. that said there is no support in IE so i might stick to translate3d for now
it’s a last resort I use. It has definitely helped with some javascript plugins/libraries like sticky-sidebar.js and stuff that uses scroll-event based code
Will change is good for things that are major movements and dom changes.
that will have the opposite effect
